[[Social conservatism]]{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/groups/390260767761431/permalink/1300064613447704/|title=Facebook Post by Ivan Grech Mintoff|website=www.facebook.com/|date=27 May 2017|accessdate=29 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2015-08-22/local-news/Alleanza-Bidla-forms-part-of-a-new-group-to-fight-the-harmful-non-gender-conformity-agenda-6736140924|title=‘Alleanza Bidla’ forms part of a new group to fight the harmful ‘non-gender conformity’ agenda|work=The Malta Independent|date=23 August 2015|accessdate=29 May 2017}}
[[Euroscepticism]]{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2016-12-18/local-news/Alleanza-Bidla-calls-on-people-fed-up-with-mainstream-politics-to-join-his-party-and-bring-change-6736168070|title=Alleanza Bidla calls on people fed up with mainstream politics to join his party and bring change|work=The Malta Independent|date=18 December 2016|accessdate=29 May 2017}} | position = [[Centre-right politics|Centre-right]] to [[Right-wing politics|Right-wing]] | headquarters = | international = | seats1_title = [[Parliament of Malta|House of Representatives]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|0|67|}} | seats2_title = [[European Parliament]] | seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|6|}} | website = {{url|http://www.alleanzabidla.com/}} | country = Malta }} '''Alleanza Bidla''' ('''AB'''; lit. "Alliance for Change") is a socially-conservative, Eurosceptic and Christian-democratic political party in [[Malta]]. ==Candidates (2017)== After going through the judicial system, Alleanza Bidla were able to nominate a total of four candidates to contest on two electoral districts each.{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2017-05-17/local-news/Not-historical-at-all-Alleanza-Bidla-told-they-cannot-field-candidates-in-more-than-two-districts-6736174373|title=Not historical at all: Alleanza Bidla told they cannot field candidates in more than two districts|work=The Malta Independent|date=17 May 2017|accessdate=29 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/court_and_police/77378/court_rules_alleanza_bidla_candidates_cannot_run_on_more_than_two_districts_each#.WSy0X-vyvIU|title=Court rules Alleanza Bidla candidates cannot run on more than two districts each|author=Matthew Agius|publisher=MaltaToday|date=19 May 2017|accessdate=29 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20170519/local/four-alleanza-bidla-candidates-to-contest-two-districts-each-court.648422|title=Four Alleanza Bidla candidates to contest two districts each, court rules|author=Edwina Brincat|publisher=Times of Malta|date=19 May 2017|accessdate=29 May 2017}} The names of the candidates (along with the electoral districts that they are contesting on) are:{{cite web|url=http://www.alleanzabidla.com/candidates/|title=Candidates|website=www.alleanzabidla.com/}} * Ivan Grech Mintoff (1st and 12th district) * Elizabeth (k/a Claire) Mikkelsen (9th and 10th district) * Joseph Giardina (7th and 12th district) * Saviour (Sonny) Xeureb (6th and 11th district) ==Election results== ===General elections=== {| class=wikitable style="text-align: left;" |- ! Election ! Leader ! Votes ! % ! Seats ! +/– ! Position ! Government |- ! {{Infobox single | Name = Begging | Cover = | Border = | Alt = | Caption = | Artist = [[Anton Ewald]] | Album = A{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/66026/sweden-anton-ewalds-a/ |title=Eurovision Sweden: Anton Ewald's 'A' |publisher=Esctoday.com |date=2013-06-25 |accessdate=2014-02-15}}{{cite web|url=http://youzeek.com/?source=vmap&lng=RU&Artist=Anton+Ewald#xPAGE_Artist_%3Flng%3DRU%26Artist%3DAnton%20Ewald%26page%3DAlbums |title=ANTON EWALD > Слушайте в начало песни, альбомы, концерты, биография |publisher=Youzeek.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-15}} | A-side = | B-side = | Released = 2013 | Format = [[CD]] | Recorded = | Genre = [[Pop music|Pop]] | Length = 3:01 https://itunes.apple.com/se/artist/anton-ewald/id597389893?l=en | Label = | Writer = {{flatlist| *[[Fredrik Kempe]] *[[Anton Malmberg Hård af Segerstad]] }} | Producer = | Certification = | Chronology = [[Anton Ewald]] | Last single = | This single = "Begging" ([[2013 in music|2013]]) | Next single = | Misc = }} '''Begging''' is a 2013 song by [[Sweden|Swedish]] singer [[Anton Ewald]].http://www.svd.se/kultur/skicka-anton-ewald-till-malmo_7979112.svd{{cite web|url=http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/artister/2013/anton-ewald/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-02-09 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130207143318/http://www.svt.se/melodifestivalen/artister/2013/anton-ewald/ |archivedate=2013-02-07 |df= }} Written by Fredrik Kempe and [[Anton Malmberg Hård af Segerstad]], it was performed in [[Melodifestivalen 2013]] in the second semi-final was held on 9 February 2013 in [[Scandinavium]], [[Gothenburg]]. Finishing 3rd/4th, it went on to the Second Chance round, where it passed through to the Melodifestivalen final after a duel with [[Behrang Miri]] and his song "[[Jalla Dansa Sawa]]". In the finals, it finished fourth in the rankings failing to qualify to [[2013 Eurovision Song Contest]]. Despite this, the song gained popularity with the Swedish public and the single was released immediately after the competition reaching number 2 on [[Sverigetopplistan]], the official Swedish Singles Chart. ==Charts== {|class="wikitable sortable" !Chart (2013) !align="center"|Peak
position |- |Sverigetopplistan [[Swedish Singles Chart]]{{cite web | url=http://swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Behrang+Miri&titel=Jalla+dansa+Sawa&cat=s | title="Jalla dansa sawa" in Swedish charts | publisher=swedishcharts.com | accessdate=5 April 2013}} |align="center"|2 |- |[[Turkish Singles Chart]][http://www.billboard.com.tr/pages/Turkiye_top20.aspx Billboard Turkiye Top 20] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080330214158/http://www.billboard.com.tr/pages/Turkiye_top20.aspx |date=2008-03-30 }} |align="center"|87 |- |} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Melodifestivalen songs of 2013]] [[Category:Songs written by Fredrik Kempe]] [[Category:Songs written by Anton Hård af Segerstad]] [[Category:2013 songs]] {{Sweden-stub}} {{2010s-song-stub}}

{{Infobox film | name = Bent Familia | image = Bent_Familia.jpg | image size = | alt = | caption = | director = [[Nouri Bouzid]] | producer = Ahmed Bahaeddine Attia | writer = | narrator = | starring = | music = | distributor = [https://web.archive.org/web/20120209151403/http://www.africanfilmlibrary.com/ Africa Film Library] | released = 1997<!-- {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | runtime = 108 minutes | country = [[Tunisia]] | language = Arabic | budget = | gross = }} '''''Bent Familia''''' is a 1997 drama set in [[Tunisia]] about Amina (Leila Nassim) a married [[Muslim]] woman living in [[Tunis]] with her two daughters. Even though she is allowed certain freedoms as a Muslim woman this is curtailed when she meets her old friend from school called Aida acted by (Amel Hédhili).
A mother of two, Aida took a firm stand not to tolerate her husband's infidelities. She divorced and considers herself a liberated woman. Then there is their mutual friend Fatiha (Nadia Kaci), an intellectual who is adamant that she is going to leave Tunis and settle in the West. This strong triangle of friendship threatens Amina's husband, Majid (Raoul Ben Amor), another adulterer who tries to bring the might of the chauvinist side of Muslim society down on her. Directed by Nouri Bouzid, this well-shot film presents us with the very real problems of women in contemporary North Africa, but offers no easy solutions.
== Casts == *Raouf Ben Amor *Kaouthar Bardi *Abderazek
== Awards == *1997: Montpellier Mediterranean Film Festival: Audience Award: Golden Antigone *1997: Namur International Festival of French-speaking Film: Best Actress *1997: [[Venice Film Festival]]: OCIC Award Honourable Mention
== Movie Trailer == *Bent-Familia [https://web.archive.org/web/20120319020521/http://www.africanfilmlibrary.com/Movies/Video/9224/135/Bent-Familia] sourced from the Africa Film Library
== External links == {{CCBYSASource|sourcepath=https://web.archive.org/web/20120319020521/http://www.africanfilmlibrary.com:80/Movies/Video/9224/135/Bent-Familia|sourcearticle=Bent Familiar|revision=478061903}} * ''Bent Familia [https://archive.is/20130422003649/http://www.mnetcorporate.co.za/ArticleDetail.aspx?Id=901]'' on mnetcorporate.co.za *{{IMDb title|0125003|Bent Familia}} *''Bent Familia [http://www.arabfilm.com/item/22/]'' on arabfilm.com *''Bent Familia [http://www.luxorafricanfilmfestival.com/Resources/filmlist/Films/bent-familia]'' on luxorafricanfilmfestival.com

{{use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{use list-defined references|date=June 2014}} {{Use British English|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox goat breed | name = Bionda dell'Adamello | image = Bionda adamello3.JPG | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | status = {{nobreak|[[FAO]] (2007): not at risk<ref name=barb/>}} | altname = {{unbulleted list|Bionda|Mustàscia}} | nickname = | country = Italy | distribution = {{unbulleted list|[[Lombardy]]|[[Trentino]]}} | standard = [http://www.assonapa.it/norme_ecc/CAPRINI-RA_Standard_WEB/Bionda.htm MIPAAF] | use = milk, also meat<ref name=bigi/> | maleweight = 70–75 kg<ref name=pulina/> | femaleweight = 55–60 kg<ref name=pulina/> | maleheight = | femaleheight = 74 cm<ref name=pulina/> | type = | skincolor = | woolcolor = from pale gold to brown | facecolor = white facial stripes | horns = males horned, females usually so<ref name=aspa3/> | beard = males bearded, females usually so<ref name=aspa3/> | tassels = present, usually white<ref name=aspa3/> | note = }} [[File:Capra, Francesco Londonio (1723–1786).jpg|thumb|300px|Painting from c. 1760 by [[Francesco Londonio]] (1723–1786), showing a goat of Bionda dell'Adamello type, with typical coat and facial markings ([[Accademia Carrara]], [[Bergamo]])]] The '''Bionda dell'Adamello''' is an indigenous [[breed]] of [[goat|domestic goat]] from the [[Val Camonica]] in the [[province of Brescia]], in [[Lombardy]] in northern Italy. It takes its name from the [[massif]] of the [[Adamello]], part of the [[Adamello-Presanella alps|Adamello-Presanella]] subsection of the [[Rhaetian Alps]]. It is raised mainly in the Val Camonica, the [[Val Saviore]] and the mountains of Brescia; some are found in neighbouring areas of the [[provinces of Italy|provinces]] of [[province of Catania|Bergamo]] to the west and [[Trentino|Trento]] to the east.<ref name=bigi/> It was in the past known simply as the '''Capra Bionda''' or as the '''Mustàscia'''.<ref name=bigi/>
==History==
The breed appears to be of ancient origin. While it shares some characteristics with the Swiss [[Toggenburger]], notably the "[[Swiss markings]]" (white facial stripes, white lower limbs and peri-anal area), it was already established well before the importation of Toggenburg billies to the area, documented from the years before and after the [[Second World War]]. A painting from about 1760 by the [[Milan]]ese painter [[Francesco Londonio]] (1723–1786) shows a goat of Bionda dell'Adamello type, with typical coat and facial markings.<ref name=bigi/>
The Bionda dell'Adamello is one of the forty-three autochthonous Italian goat breeds of limited distribution for which a herdbook is kept by the [[Associazione Nazionale della Pastorizia]], the Italian national association of sheep- and goat-breeders.<ref name=dm/><ref name=aspa/> The herd-book was activated in 1997.<ref name=pulina/> At the end of 2013 the registered population was variously reported as 3148<ref name=aspa2/> and as 2772.<ref name=dad/>
==Use==
The [[goat's milk|milk]] yield per [[lactation]] of the Bionda dell'Adamello is {{nowrap|303 ± 108 litres}} for [[secondiparous]], and {{nowrap|361 ± 122 l}} for [[pluriparous]], nannies.<ref name=aspa/> The milk averages 3.16% fat and 2.97% [[protein]]. It is used mostly to make [[Mascarpì]], a kind of [[ricotta]], and the smoked [[caprino cheese]] [[Fatulì]], which has [[Prodotto alimentare tradizionale|PAT]] status and is listed in the [[Slow Food]] [[Ark of Taste]].<ref name=bigi/>
==References== {{reflist|refs=
<ref name=aspa>[http://www.assonapa.it/Pubblicazioni/Razze-ovine-caprine-Italia/Razze_Ovine_Caprine_Italia.pdf Le razze ovine e caprine in Italia] (in Italian). Associazione Nazionale della Pastorizia: Ufficio centrale libri genealogici e registri anagrafici razze ovine e caprine. p. 91. Accessed June 2014.</ref>
<ref name=aspa2>[http://www.assonapa.it/Consistenze/Cons_razza.asp?Anno=2013&Cod_razza=43 Consistenze Provinciali della Razza 43 Bionda dell'Adamello Anno 2013] (in Italian). Associazione Nazionale della Pastorizia: Banca dati. Accessed June 2014.</ref>
<ref name=aspa3>[http://www.assonapa.it/norme_ecc/CAPRINI-RA_Standard_WEB/Bionda.htm Norme tecniche della popolazione caprina "Bionda dell'Adamello": standard della razza] (in Italian). Associazione Nazionale della Pastorizia. Accessed June 2014.</ref>
<ref name=barb>Barbara Rischkowsky, D. Pilling (eds.) (2007). [ftp://ftp.fao.org/docrep/fao/010/a1250e/annexes/List%20of%20breeds%20documented%20in%20the%20Global%20Databank%20for%20Animal%20Genetic%20Resources/List_breeds.pdf List of breeds documented in the Global Databank for Animal Genetic Resources], annex to [ftp://ftp.fao.org/docrep/fao/010/a1250e/a1250e.pdf ''The State of the World's Animal Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture'']. Rome: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. {{ISBN|9789251057629}}. Accessed June 2014.</ref>
<ref name=bigi>Daniele Bigi, Alessio Zanon (2008). ''Atlante delle razze autoctone: Bovini, equini, ovicaprini, suini allevati in Italia'' (in Italian). Milan: Edagricole. {{ISBN|9788850652594}}. p. 321–23.</ref>
<ref name=dad>[http://dad.fao.org/cgi-bin/EfabisWeb.cgi?sid=0b1613ebf16355cf65f6a05b9a65fe25,reportsreport8a_50006859 Breed data sheet: Bionda dell'Adamello/Italy]. Domestic Animal Diversity Information System of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations. Accessed June 2014.</ref>
<ref name=dm>[https://web.archive.org/web/20140504172524/http://www.politicheagricole.it/flex/cm/pages/ServeAttachment.php/L/IT/D/1/f/9/D.8551668d49c199df1401/P/BLOB%3AID%3D2023 Strutture Zootecniche (Dec. 2009/712/CE - Allegato 2 - Capitolo 2)] (in Italian). Ministero delle Politiche Agricole Alimentari e Forestali. Section '''I''' (e). Archived 4 December 2013.</ref>
<ref name=pulina>Lorenzo Noè, Alessandro Gaviraghi, Andrea D'Angelo, Adriana Bonanno, Adriana Di Trana, Lucia Sepe, Salvatore Claps, Giovanni Annicchiarico, Nicola Bacciu (2005). [https://web.archive.org/web/20141005120512/http://www.istitutospallanzani.it/doc/220.pdf Le razze caprine d'Italia] (in Italian); in: Giuseppe Pulina (2005). ''L' alimentazione della capra da latte''. Bologna: Avenue Media. {{ISBN|9788886817493}}. {{nobreak|p. 381–435.}} Archived 5 October 2014.</ref>

{{refimprove|date=October 2007}} [[File:Caverio Map circa 1506.jpg|thumb|300px|The Caverio Map]]
The '''Caverio Map''' (also known as Caveri Map or Canerio Map) is a map drawn by [[Nicolay de Caveri]], circa 1506. It is kept at the [[Bibliothèque Nationale de France]] in Paris.
It is drawn on parchment by hand and coloured. It is composed of ten sections or panels, the whole forming a rectangle measuring 2.25 by 1.15 metres. This undated map was one of the primary sources used to make the [[Waldseemüller map]] in 1507. On the basis of this it is mostly dated to c. 1506. The map is signed with "Nicolay de Caveri Januensis". It was probably either made in [[Lisbon]] by the Genoese Canveri, or copied by him in Genoa from a Portuguese map very similar to the [[Cantino planisphere|Cantino map]], if not the Cantino map itself. The Cantino map was in Genoa toward the end of 1502 and presumably the following few years, when Caveri could have used it as the basis of his map.
Sanz (1961){{page needed|date=February 2016}} argued that the east coast of North America is drawn with surprising accuracy, especially "when we consider the general belief that the Europeans neither saw nor set foot on the beaches in the southern states of the present-day U.S.A. before [[Juan Ponce de León|Ponce de León]] arrived there in 1512 or 1513, [[Giovanni da Verrazzano]] in 1523, [[Lucas Vásquez de Ayllón]] in 1520-1524 or [[Esteban Gómez]] in 1525."
==See also== *[[Early world maps]] *[[Piri Reis map]]
==References== *Carlos Sanz, ''Mapas antiguos del mundo'', Madrid, 1961.
==External links== *[http://visualiseur.bnf.fr/CadresFenetre?O=IFN-7759102&I=1&M=chemindefer Zoomable image of the Caverio map on the Bibliothèque Nationale de France website]
[[Category:Historic maps of the world]] [[Category:1505 works]] [[Category:Bibliothèque nationale de France collections]] [[Category:16th-century maps and globes]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Poland}} "Chcę znać swój grzech..." | image = | caption = | year = 1996 | country = Poland | artist = [[Kasia Kowalska]] | as = | with = | language = Polish | languages = | composer = Robert Amirian | lyricist = [[Kasia Kowalska]] | conductor = Wieslaw Pieregorólka | place = 15th | points = 31 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1996pl from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Sama | prev_link = Sama (song) | next = Ale jestem | next_link = Ale jestem }} '''"Chcę znać swój grzech..."''' (I want to know my sin...) was the [[Poland|Polish]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1996]], performed in [[Polish language|Polish]] by [[Kasia Kowalska]].<ref>[http://www.diggiloo.net/?1996pl Chcę znać swój grzech], Diggiloo.net. Retrieved 12 February 2018</ref>
The song is a dramatic ballad, with Kowalska asking a lover to tell her the reason for his coldness towards her. She refers to this reason as "my sin", and asks him to tell it to her "Only once/Before I lose you", claiming that if she knows this she will redouble her efforts to love him.
The song was performed twentieth on the night, following [[Iceland]]'s [[Anna Mjöll Ólafsdóttir|Anna Mjöll]] with "[[Sjúbídú]]" and preceding [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]'s [[Amila Glamočak]] with "[[Za našu ljubav]]". At the close of voting, it had received 31 points, placing 15th in a field of 23.
The promotional video featured Kasia singing in a church, surrounded by candles
It was succeeded as [[Poland in the Eurovision Song Contest|Polish representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1997|1997 Contest]] by [[Anna Maria Jopek]] with "[[Ale jestem]]".
==References== <references />
{{Poland in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{Eurovision Song Contest 1996}}

revision.text:
[[File:21.09.2011 Conectar Igualdad en la Antártida Argentina Artartida2 (6186143757).jpg|thumb|Children, adolescents and teachers of the school of [[Esperanza Base]].]] [[Antarctica]] has few permanent residents, and contains research stations and field camps that are staffed seasonally or year-round, and former [[whaling]] settlements.[http://www.coolantarctica.com/Antarctica%20fact%20file/science/can_you_live_in_antarctica.php Cool Antarctica: Who lives in Antarctica?] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160112000000/http://www.coolantarctica.com/Antarctica%20fact%20file/science/can_you_live_in_antarctica.php |date=January 12, 2016 }} The largest station, [[McMurdo Station]], has a summer population of about 1,000 people and a winter population of about 200.https://www.nsf.gov/geo/plr/support/mcmurdo.jsp NSF: McMurdo Station] Approximately 29 nations, all signatory to the [[Antarctic Treaty]], send personnel to perform seasonal (summer) or year-round research on the continent and in its surrounding oceans. The population of persons doing and supporting scientific research on the continent and its nearby islands south of [[60th parallel south|60 degrees south]] latitude (the region covered by the Antarctic Treaty){{cite web|url=http://www.ats.aq/e/ats.htm|title=ATS - The Antarctic Treaty|author=|date=|website=www.ats.aq}} varies from approximately 4,000 in summer to 1,000 in winter; in addition, approximately 1,000 personnel including ship's crew and scientists doing onboard research are present in the waters of the treaty region. At least ten children have been born in West Antarctica. The first was [[Emilio Palma|Emilio Marcos Palma]], born on 7 January 1978 to [[Argentina|Argentine]] parents at [[Esperanza Base|Esperanza]], Hope Bay, near the tip of the Antarctic peninsula.{{cite web|url=http://webecoist.com/2011/02/15/born-freezing-meet-antarcticas-first-citizen/|title=Born Freezing: Meet Antarctica's First Citizen - WebEcoist|author=|date=15 February 2011|website=webecoist.com}} In 1984, [[Juan Pablo Camacho]] was born at the [[Villa Las Estrellas|Presidente Eduardo Frei Montalva Base]], becoming the first [[Chile]]an born in Antarctica. Soon after, a girl, Gisella, was born at the same station. In 2001, ''National Geographic'' reported that eight children had been born at Esperanza alone. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! Nation ! Summer

revision.text:
{{Infobox airport | name = Iqaluit Airport | image =Iqaluit-airport.jpg | caption = The old terminal | IATA = YFB | ICAO = CYFB | WMO = 71909 | type = Public | owner = Government of Nunavut | operator = Nunavut Airport Services Ltd. | city-served = | hub = *[[Canadian North]] *[[First Air]] | location = [[Iqaluit]], [[Nunavut]] | timezone = [[Eastern Time Zone|EST]] | utc = [[UTC−05:00]] | summer = EDT | utcs = [[UTC−04:00]] | elevation-f = 110 | coordinates = {{coord|63|45|24|N|068|33|22|W|region:CA-NU|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = Canada Nunavut | pushpin_label = CYFB | r1-number = 16/34 | r1-length-f = 8,605 | r1-surface = Asphalt | stat-year = 2011/2010 | stat1-header = Passengers | stat1-data = 120,040 | stat2-header = Aircraft movements | stat2-data = 20,178 | footnotes = Sources: [[Canada Flight Supplement]]{{CFS}}
[[Environment Canada]][http://climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/prods_servs/metstat1_e.html Synoptic/Metstat Station Information] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130627233755/http://climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/prods_servs/metstat1_e.html |date=2013-06-27 }}
Movements from [[Statistics Canada]]{{cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/51-209-x/2011001/t001-eng.htm|title=Aircraft Movement Statistics: NAV CANADA Towers and Flight Service Stations: Annual Report (TP 577): Table 2-2 — Total aircraft movements by class of operation — NAV CANADA flight service stations|author=|date=|website=www.statcan.gc.ca|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20121123105343/http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/51-209-x/2011001/t001-eng.htm|archivedate=23 November 2012|df=}}}} '''Iqaluit Airport''' {{Airport codes|YFB|CYFB}} serves [[Iqaluit]], [[Nunavut]], Canada and is located adjacent to the city. It is operated by the [[government of Nunavut]]. It hosts [[Airline|scheduled passenger service]] from [[Ottawa]], [[Montreal]], [[Rankin Inlet]], and [[Kuujjuaq]] on carriers such as [[First Air]] and [[Canadian North]], and from smaller communities throughout eastern Nunavut. It is also used as a [[forward operating base]] by the [[CF-18 Hornet]]. In 2011, the terminal handled more than 120,000 passengers.{{cite web |url=http://www.edt.gov.nu.ca/apps/UPLOADS/fck/file/Iqaluit_Airport_four_pager.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140418160816/http://www.edt.gov.nu.ca/apps/UPLOADS/fck/file/Iqaluit_Airport_four_pager.pdf |archivedate=2014-04-18 |df= }} The airport is classified as an [[airport of entry]] by [[Nav Canada]] and is staffed by the [[Canada Border Services Agency]] (CBSA). CBSA officers at this airport can handle [[general aviation]] aircraft only, with no more than 15 passengers. The airport serves as a [[diversion airport]] on [[polar route]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.boeing.com/commercial/aeromagazine/aero_16/polar_fig3.html|title=Figure 3. Boeing-Conducted Airport Safety And Operational Assessments|author=|date=|website=www.boeing.com|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171013235137/http://www.boeing.com/commercial/aeromagazine/aero_16/polar_fig3.html|archivedate=13 October 2017|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.boeing.com/commercial/aeromagazine/aero_16/polar_fig1.html|title=Figure 1. New Cross-Polar Routes Via The North Polar Region|author=|date=|website=www.boeing.com|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170923164056/http://www.boeing.com/commercial/aeromagazine/aero_16/polar_fig1.html|archivedate=23 September 2017|df=}} The airport is owned by the Government of Nunavut (GN){{cite web|url=http://www.tc.gc.ca/programs/Airports/Status/menu.htm|title=The page has moved - La page a été déménagée|author=|date=|website=www.tc.gc.ca|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303224638/http://www.tc.gc.ca/eng/programs/airports-status-menu-441.htm|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=}} and operated, under a 30-year contract, by Nunavut Airport Services. The company is a subsidiary of Winnipeg Airport Services Corporation, which in turn is a subsidiary of Winnipeg Airports Authority.[http://www.waa.ca/waa/wasco Winnipeg Airport Services Corporation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161211063920/http://www.waa.ca/waa/wasco |date=2016-12-11 }} ==History== ===Military use=== During late July 1941, a [[United States Army Air Forces]] (USAAF) team headed by Captain [[Elliott Roosevelt]] investigated the [[Frobisher Bay]] region for a potential airport for use in trans-Atlantic air traffic. Roosevelt's report designated a marginal site at Cape Rammelsberg for later construction. In mid-October, trawlers ''Lark'', ''Polarbjoern'', and ''Selis'' reached the vicinity, but owing to inaccurate charts (dating from the 1865 expedition of [[Charles Francis Hall]]) could not find the Roosevelt site. Instead, an eight-man crew commanded by USAAF Captain John T. Crowell was offloaded on a smaller island "about eight miles southeast of the headland Captain Roosevelt had recommended."Forbes, 59–65 They operated a weather/radio station over the winter. The expedition reported that "this island is reported to be some 400 feet high and very level on top providing a natural runway of more than a mile in length." The ships left on 5 November.Hubbard Report When the station relief and base construction expedition arrived next July, both the Crowell and Roosevelt sites were rejected in favour of a level meadow discovered along the Sylvia Grinnell River on mainland [[Baffin Island]]. On 30 July, ships ''Polaris'' and ''[[Effie M. Morrissey]]'' anchored in what was then called Koojesse Inlet and began surveying the area: "The terrain was excellent, with level ground extending nearly the entire 6,000 feet needed for an ample runway...The harbor, readily accessible from the bay, offered a good anchorage for ships of any size that would come in."Forbes, 71 The expedition consisted further of the [[USS Bear (1874)|USCGC ''Bear'']], equipped with a seaplane, the transports ''Fairfax'' and ''Eleanor'' and some smaller vessels. Having offloaded the airport construction crews and materials, the expedition left at the end of September. [[File:Frobisher Bay, Baffin Island, aeronautical chart section.jpg|thumb|Frobisher Bay airport approaches with original station sites noted. USDOD ONC D-15, 1971]] ===World War II=== By summer of 1943, the airbase at Koojesse Inlet had "grown to look like a populous village" and was in use by many aircraft.Forbes, 116 It was designated Crystal II and referred to as ''Chaplet'' in coded communications. It was one of three "Crystal" weather sites in the Canadian Arctic Region, [[Kuujjuaq|Fort Chimo]] (now Kuujjuaq), [[Quebec]] being "Crystal I", and a station on [[Padloping Island]] being "Crystal III". A detachment of the 8th Weather Squadron, [[Air Transport Command (United States Air Force)|Air Transport Command]] (ATC) took up residence at the station on October 1, 1942.{{cite web|url=http://airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/076/387.xml|title=USAFHRA Document 00076387|author=|date=|website=airforcehistoryindex.org|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724230904/http://airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/076/387.xml|archivedate=24 July 2011|df=}} The initial mission of the Crystal sites was to provide long-range weather information to the combat forces then building up in the [[United Kingdom]]. As part of the [[Crimson Route|Crimson East]] air route network, the airfield at Crystal II was referred to by USAAF Air Transport Command as ATC Station #10.{{cite web|url=http://airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/180/777.xml|title=USAFHRA Document 00180777|author=|date=|website=airforcehistoryindex.org|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724230910/http://airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/180/777.xml|archivedate=24 July 2011|df=}} It was intended to be a transport hub between the Eastern Route, which originated at [[Presque Isle Air Force Base|Presque Isle Army Airfield]], Maine and the Central Route, which originated at [[Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport|Romulus Army Airfield]] (Detroit Airport), Michigan. The original plan, briefed by Captain Roosevelt to USAAF Chief [[Henry H. Arnold|Henry "Hap" Arnold]] and others at the [[Argentia]] summit in August 1941, called for Frobisher Bay to be a node in a northern alternate air route, running from [[Churchill, Manitoba]] via [[Southampton Island]] over Frobisher to [[Sondrestrom Air Base|Bluie West Eight]] and [[Bluie East Two]] in Greenland, rejoining the main route in Iceland.Hansen, 199–200, 211–215 The later success of the main air route via [[Narsarsuaq Air Base|Bluie West One]] and the spring 1943 victory in the [[Battle of the Atlantic]] led to cancelation of the Crimson project in late 1943, and the associated airfields were reduced to weather, communications, and logistics duties.{{cite web|url=http://airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/076/350.xml|title=AFHRA Document 00076350|author=|date=|website=airforcehistoryindex.org|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811063933/http://airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/076/350.xml|archivedate=11 August 2011|df=}} The use of Frobisher Bay declined with the end of World War II, with jurisdiction of the facility being transferred to [[Military Air Transport Service]] (MATS) in 1948, under its [[Air Weather Service]]. During the 1950s it continued to be used as a transit point by the [[United States]] and Canada. The base was closed in 1963 and converted into a civilian airport. ===Civilian use=== Since the 1950s, Frobisher Bay had earned a reputation{{by whom|date=July 2018}} as a [[wiktionary:technical stop|technical stop]] for airlines flying the [[Atlantic Ocean|North Atlantic]]. Crews departing westward from [[Glasgow Prestwick Airport|Prestwick]] or [[Shannon Airport|Shannon]] in those years preferred to route via [[Iceland]] (or the [[Azores]]) to [[Gander International Airport|Gander]], thence to [[New York City]] or elsewhere. Weather, however, could dictate a northerly course, which is when Frobisher Bay came into its own. At one time,{{when|date=July 2018}} [[Pan American World Airways|Pan American]] even had a base there and on at least two occasions had to change engines on [[Douglas DC-7]]Cs at Frobisher Bay. With the introduction of the intercontinental [[Boeing 707]] and [[Douglas DC-8]], fewer airlines stopped at Iqaluit. Even so, there always seemed to be some activity.{{according to|date=July 2018}} The place remained prominent as a regional airport, continued in its strategic role of sustaining the [[Distant Early Warning Line]] (DEW), supported the occasional military exercise or scientific expedition, and was still{{when|date=July 2018}} a key stopover on the North Atlantic ferry route. Through the 1960s, [[Nordair]] was the main airline serving Frobisher Bay from Montreal, {{Convert|1100|NM}} to the south. [[Douglas DC-4]]s operated into the 1970s and [[Lockheed Corporation|Lockheed]] [[Lockheed Constellation|Super Constellation]]s between 1964 and 1969. In 1968 Nordair introduced the [[Boeing 737|Boeing 737-200]] on the Frobisher Bay run. At the same time, Bradley Air Services had been expanding. By the 1970s, the company's fleet of [[de Havilland Canada]] [[de Havilland Canada DHC-6 Twin Otter|DHC-6 Twin Otter]]s and [[Douglas DC-3]]s was serving many small [[Arctic]] communities from YFB, carrying passengers, mail, groceries, and other essentials. Bradley became known as First Air in 1973 and soon added [[Hawker Siddeley HS 748|BAe 748]]s. In the 1980s, Canada's airline industry was in transition, with [[Air Canada]] and [[Canadian Airlines]] rapidly buying up regional operators. Air Canada acquired Nordair in 1977, and then sold it in 1984 to Canadian Airlines. Jet service to Iqaluit Airport continued, but under the [[Canadian North]] banner, which was, after the buyout of Canadian Airlines by Air Canada, to continue operations as an independent airline, jointly owned by the [[Inuit]] of the [[Northwest Territories]] and Nunavut. Between 1985 and 1988 First Air added four [[Boeing 727]]s to link Montreal and Ottawa with Iqaluit. Meanwhile, Canadian Airlines failed, and was taken over by Air Canada in 2000. In 1995 First Air purchased the small [[Yellowknife]]-based carrier Ptarmigan Airways; then, in 1997, [[Northwest Territorial Airways]] (NWT Air), Air Canada's Yellowknife subsidiary. In the NWT Air move First Air acquired two 737-200 [[Combi aircraft|Combi]]s and a Lockheed [[Lockheed L-100 Hercules|382 Hercules]].''Airways'' (June 2006) ''Pages 24-28'' ''YFB and First Air'' ==Facilities== *2 hangar/cargo terminals (First Air/Canadian North) - hangar was terminal building until 1986{{cite web|url=https://chriswindeyer.com/writing/the-new-iqaluit-airport/|title=Protected Blog › Log in|author=|date=|website=chriswindeyer.com|accessdate=4 May 2018}} *1 two-storey terminal building c. 1986 *1 main runway *three aprons *1 FBO (Frobisher Bay Touchdown Services) *administration and control tower (former terminal) Iqaluit International Airport Fire Department operates one crash tender for local fire suppression and has support from [[Iqaluit Fire Department]] when needed. ==Terminal== The main terminal (c.1986) has: *Check-in desks *3 gates *1 baggage claim belt *Gift shop *Travel agent *Tourist help desk *Car rental *Taxi service/rank *Baby/parent room *Disabled access/facilities *30 short term parking spaces * display cases for local artwork The new terminal has: *16 Check-in desks{{cite web|url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674iqaluits_new_airport_big_bold_and_beautiful/|title=Nunatsiaq News 2017-05-29: NEWS: Iqaluit’s new airport: big, bold and beautiful|author=|date=|website=www.nunatsiaqonline.ca|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180112222908/http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674iqaluits_new_airport_big_bold_and_beautiful/|archivedate=12 January 2018|df=}} * 5 gates * 2 baggage claim carousel * departures conveyor belt to carry baggage to screening area * café{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/iqaluit-airport-opens-1.4239486|title=Iqaluit's new $300M airport opens today - CBC News|author=|date=|website=cbc.ca|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171121233311/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/iqaluit-airport-opens-1.4239486|archivedate=21 November 2017|df=}} * passenger waiting lounge * store * gift shop * travel agent desk * tourist help desk * car rental desk * taxi service * parenting room * central rotunda * assessable entrance and gates * 100 parking spaces * Art work: Kenojuak Ashevak's Enchanted Owl - mural in the rotunda and Duffell wall hangings ==Future development== As a result of increased traffic, the Nunavut government planned an overhaul of the airport that was expected to cost $250–300 million. The project was a [[public–private partnership]] with the GN borrowing their half of the cost. Nunavut Airport Services will operate the airport for 30 years. Upgrades included: * new {{convert|100,000|ft2|abbr=on}} terminal building constructed by [[Bouygues]][http://www.bouygues.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/bouygues_2015_registration_document1.pdf 2015 Registration Document] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160604033152/http://www.bouygues.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/bouygues_2015_registration_document1.pdf |date=2016-06-04 }} page 36 * retrofitting the current terminal which will become solely an administration building and control tower * expanding parking lots * new combined services building to house all airport and safety vehicles * a second taxiway * apron and repaving the runway. The construction began in 2014 and was completed on August 8, 2017, with flight service beginning the following day.{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/story/2012/07/06/north-iqaluit-airport-rennovations.html |title=Iqaluit airport to be overhauled by 2017 |publisher=CBC |date=2012-07-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120707161441/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/story/2012/07/06/north-iqaluit-airport-rennovations.html |archivedate=2012-07-07 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674new_public-private_iqaluit_airport_to_cost_up_to_300_million/ |title=New public-private Iqaluit airport to cost up to $300 million |publisher=Nunatsiaq News |date=2012-07-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216004226/http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674new_public-private_iqaluit_airport_to_cost_up_to_300_million/ |archivedate=2014-12-16 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://nationtalk.ca/story/new-iqaluit-international-airport-terminal-opening/ |title=New Iqaluit International Airport terminal opening |publisher=NationTalk |date=2017-08-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029065843/http://nationtalk.ca/story/new-iqaluit-international-airport-terminal-opening |archivedate=2017-10-29 |df= }} On September 5, 2015, during construction, a large fire caused major damage to the roof of the new terminal, costing an estimated $1 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/iqaluit-airport-fire-damage-1.3222831 |title=Iqaluit airport terminal fire damage estimated at $1M |publisher=CBC |date=2015-09-10 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160811101405/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/iqaluit-airport-fire-damage-1.3222831 |archivedate=2016-08-11 |df= }} ==Other information== Over the years several international flights have been diverted to Iqaluit due to technical reasons,{{cite web|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/flight-from-zurich-to-l-a-diverts-to-iqaluit-after-engine-shuts-down-1.3267034|title=Flight from Zurich to L.A. diverts to Iqaluit after engine shuts down|author=|date=1 February 2017|website=ctvnews.ca|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029082757/http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/flight-from-zurich-to-l-a-diverts-to-iqaluit-after-engine-shuts-down-1.3267034|archivedate=29 October 2017|df=}} [[air rage]]{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/passenger-diverted-aeroflot-flight-iqaluit-plea-1.3964618|title=Accused passenger from diverted Aeroflot flight tries to plead guilty - CBC News|author=|date=|website=cbc.ca|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170217135525/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/passenger-diverted-aeroflot-flight-iqaluit-plea-1.3964618|archivedate=17 February 2017|df=}} or on-board medical emergencies with no deaths being reported.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/moscow-to-l-a-flight-makes-emergency-landing-in-iqaluit-1.3257521?cmp=rss |title=Moscow to L.A. flight makes emergency landing in Iqaluit |publisher=CBC |date=2015-10-05 |accessdate=2015-10-06 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151113223759/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/moscow-to-l-a-flight-makes-emergency-landing-in-iqaluit-1.3257521?cmp=rss |archivedate=2015-11-13 |df= }} On 31 May 1996, [[Virgin Atlantic Airways|Virgin Atlantic]] flight 7 from [[London]] to [[Los Angeles]] made an [[emergency landing]] at Iqaluit after a passenger had a heart attack. The landing was executed safely - the first [[Boeing 747]] ever to attempt to land at Iqaluit - but one of the 747's engines hit a fuel pump on the tarmac as it was taxiing, causing serious damage to the aircraft and a potentially dangerous fuel spill. The 397 stranded passengers, including singer [[Gary Barlow]], were flown out after Virgin Atlantic chartered two jets. The passengers, after spending 16 hours in a local [[curling]] rink, were taken to New York to catch connecting flights to Los Angeles. [[Prince Michael of Kent]], who had also been on the flight, was given a [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] escort and departed on an earlier scheduled flight. The original aircraft had its engines repaired and left four days after the accident. The heart-attack victim survived.{{cite web|url=http://www.nunatsiaq.com/archives/back-issues/week/60607.html#7|title=Unexpected Arctic stop for Brits, Yanks|author=|date=|website=nunatsiaq.com|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090514054733/http://www.nunatsiaq.com/archives/back-issues/week/60607.html#7|archivedate=14 May 2009|df=}} [[File:Airbus A380 in Iqaluit 02.jpg|thumb|Airbus A380 at Iqaluit]] The [[Airbus A380]], the world's largest passenger jet, conducted cold weather testing from Iqaluit Airport during February 2006 - its first North American visit. They were hoping to experience {{convert|-25|C|0}} weather to determine the effects on cabin temperatures and engine performance. Nunavut authorities hope that the importance of these tests will put Iqaluit on the map as a centre for cold-weather testing.{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2006/02/10/airbus060310.html |title=Jumbo Airbus getting cold, and more, during Iqaluit tests |publisher=CBC |date=2006-02-10 |accessdate =2010-04-12}} In February 2013, [[Airbus Military]] used the airport to test the [[Airbus A400M Atlas]] military transport aircraft that is currently being developed.[http://www.airbusmilitary.com/LatestNews/tabid/176/ArticleID/250/ArtMID/681/Airbus-Military-A400M-undergoes-latest-cold-weather-tests.aspx Airbus Military A400M undergoes latest cold weather tests] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130321215847/http://www.airbusmilitary.com/LatestNews/tabid/176/ArticleID/250/ArtMID/681/Airbus-Military-A400M-undergoes-latest-cold-weather-tests.aspx |date=2013-03-21 }} The city government sent a delegation to [[Paris Airshow]] in June 2013 to promote Iqaluit as an ideal location for these tests. [[Airbus A350]] followed suit and conducted its cold weather testing in January 2014. Airport staff cited low landing fee, sufficient runway length, and minimal air traffic movement all helped in the decision making.{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/airbus-s-new-a350-in-iqaluit-for-cold-weather-testing-1.2512504 |title=Airbus's new A350 in Iqaluit for cold weather testing |date=2014-01-27 |publisher=CBC News |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140131194653/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/airbus-s-new-a350-in-iqaluit-for-cold-weather-testing-1.2512504 |archivedate=2014-01-31 |df= }} Following from these previous successful visits by prototype Airbus aircraft, the company sent the first [[A320neo]] with [[CFM International LEAP]] engines to be tested in January 2016. As part of the type's first visit to [[North America]], the jet performed several circuits in the subzero temperatures before departing back to [[Toulouse–Blagnac Airport]].{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/airbus-a320neo-cold-test-iqaluit-1.3422936 |title=Airbus cold-weather tests its A320neo in Iqaluit |date=2016-01-28 |publisher=CBC News |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170205100815/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/airbus-a320neo-cold-test-iqaluit-1.3422936 |archivedate=2017-02-05 |df= }} In December 2005 the Government of Nunavut announced that it would spend $40 million to repair the runway, build a new emergency services facility and a new terminal.{{cite web|url=http://www.nunatsiaq.com/archives/51216/news/nunavut/51216_11.html|title=Nunatsiaq News|author=|date=|website=nunatsiaq.com|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20060206222721/http://www.nunatsiaq.com/archives/51216/news/nunavut/51216_11.html|archivedate=6 February 2006|df=}} In January 2012 [[Air Greenland]] announced that a 1-hour, 45-minute flight from [[Nuuk]] to Iqaluit, down from three days when going via Copenhagen or Reykjavik and then on to Ottawa, would begin 18 June 2012, later changed to 15 June. The service was a partnership with [[First Air]] who provided ticketing and other services in Iqaluit. This was the first international flight into Iqaluit since 2001 when First Air discontinued its Iqaluit to [[Kangerlussuaq]] flights. Air Greenland used [[Bombardier Dash 8|Dash 8]] aircraft on the run.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/story/2012/06/07/north-greenland-first-air.html | title=Air Greenland teams with First Air for Iqaluit flights | date=8 June 2012 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120610195403/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/story/2012/06/07/north-greenland-first-air.html | archivedate=10 June 2012 | df= }}{{cite news|url=http://www.airgreenland.com/nyhedsvisning/?newsid=1030 |work=Air Greenland |title=Air Greenland opens summer-route to Canada |date=18 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130518084537/http://www.airgreenland.com/nyhedsvisning/?newsid=1030 |archivedate=18 May 2013 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674iqaluit-nuuk_flights_ready_for_june_15_take-off/|title=Nunatsiaq News 2012-05-28: NEWS: Iqaluit-Nuuk service ready for June 15 take-off|author=|date=|website=www.nunatsiaqonline.ca|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180213202304/http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674iqaluit-nuuk_flights_ready_for_june_15_take-off|archivedate=13 February 2018|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674iqaluit_welcomes_new_air_link/|title=Nunatsiaq News 2012-01-18: NEWS: Tireless lobbying led to Iqaluit-Greenland air link revival|author=|date=|website=www.nunatsiaqonline.ca|accessdate=4 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180213025756/http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674iqaluit_welcomes_new_air_link/|archivedate=13 February 2018|df=}} After three years in place the service was discontinued for the 2015 season.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/air-greenland-cuts-nuuk-iqaluit-scheduled-flights-in-2015-1.2985006 | title=Air Greenland cuts Nuuk-Iqaluit scheduled flights in 2015 | date=6 March 2015 | publisher=CBC News | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151115142652/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/air-greenland-cuts-nuuk-iqaluit-scheduled-flights-in-2015-1.2985006 | archivedate=15 November 2015 | df= }} to Ottawa and Montreal from March 2010 to August 1, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/stories/article/65674iqaluit_flyers_say_theyll_miss_air_canada/|title=Nunatsiaq News 2011-07-05: Air Baffin began as chartered service in 1989, as a schedule airline in 1992 and renamed as Air Nunavut in 1996. === Cargo === {| class="wikitable" !Airlines !Destinations |- |[[Canadian North]] [[Cargojet|Cargojet Airways]] |[[Kuujjuaq Airport|Kuujjuaq]], [[Montréal–Pierre Elliott Trudeau International Airport|Montréal–Trudeau]] |- |[[Purolator Inc.|Purolator Courier]] operated by [[Cargojet|Cargojet Airways]] |[[Calgary International Airport|Calgary]] |} ==Accidents and incidents== *On 12 February 1973, [[Douglas C-47|Douglas C-47A]] C-FOOV of [[Kenting Atlas Aviation]] crashed on approach. The aircraft was on a ferry flight to [[Resolute Bay Airport]] when power was lost shortly after take-off from Iqaluit and the decision was made to return. All three people on board survived.{{cite web |url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19730212-0 |title=CF-OOV Accident description |publisher=Aviation Safety Network |accessdate=26 August 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20100826181146/http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19730212-0 |archivedate=26 August 2010 |df= }} *On 14 August 1996, a [[Canadian Forces]] [[CF-18 Hornet]] left the runway during [[takeoff]], slid down an embankment and ruptured a fuel pipeline. The aircraft caught fire, as did fuel spilling from the pipeline, however the pilot had ejected just as the plane left the runway and suffered a broken ankle. The pipeline was shut down and the fire brought under control in less than an hour.[http://www.nunatsiaq.com/archives/back-issues/week/60816.html#1 Pilot ejects in nick of time as CF-18 crashes while attempting to take off.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071107084849/http://www.nunatsiaq.com/archives/back-issues/week/60816.html |date=2007-11-07 }} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} {{Can-arpt-wx|CYFB|Iqaluit Airport}} *[http://polarpilots.ca: Website of local private pilot group based at CYFB] {{List of airports in Canada}} [[Category:Certified airports in the Qikiqtaaluk Region]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Iqaluit]] [[Category:WAAS reference stations]] [[Category:Transport in Iqaluit]] [[Category:National Airports System]] [[Category:Airports established in 1942]] [[Category:1942 establishments in Canada]]

revision.text:
The '''National Health Accounts''' is a process through which countries monitor the flow of money in their health sector. Looking at different perspective of health financing. The [[World Health Organization]] has been coordinating efforts at the global level to produce those estimates for each and every country.<ref>World Health Statistics 2011</ref>
==History== {{Expand section|date=August 2017}} On the 1948 the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) constitution was the Universal Health Coverage (UHC) firmly based. For the monitoring of the UHC it is essential to measure how health systems are financed. The measurement of the health systems are based on data generated by the National Health Accounts. National Health Accounts have been developed using the System of Health Accounts (SHA) defined by [[OECD]]. The SHA has been developed since 2000. National Health Accounts have been produced in most developing countries between 2002 and 2009. A new version of SHA has been released in 2011.<ref>A system of health accounts, 10 Oct 2011, 522 pages http://www.oecd-ilibrary.org/social-issues-migration-health/a-system-of-health-accounts_9789264116016-en</ref>
==Basic Structure== Every expenditure in the health system is classified according to characteristics. The three major categories are : Health Care Functions, Health Care Providers, Health Care Financing Schemes. Within each category, you find a number of subcategories.
'''Example of subcategories in Health Care Financing Schemes'''
=== Public expenses === *[[Tax]] *Mandatory [[Health Insurance]] - Social *Security- [[Hypothecated tax|Earmarked taxes]] *Public Donor funding
=== Private expenses === *Direct Household Expenses (OOP) *[[Non Governmental Organisation]] *[[Private insurance]] - [[Community Insurance]] *Health expenses by companies
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons|World Health Organization}} *[http://www.who.int/nha/en/ World Health Organization - National Health Accounts]
[[Category:World Health Organization]]

page.title: Postage stamps and postal history of Andorra

revision.text:
{{Expand Russian|История почты и почтовых марок Андорры|date=January 2015}} [[File:Buzón de Correos en Andorra.jpg|thumb|right|An Andorran post box]] '''[[Andorra]]''', officially the ''Principality of Andorra'', is a small country located in the [[Pyrenees]] mountains and bordered by Spain and France. The official language is [[Catalan language|Catalan]], although Spanish, French, and Portuguese are also commonly spoken.
Postal services in Andorra are unique in that they are not operated by the country itself, but by its two larger neighbouring countries, [[Spain]] and [[France]].<ref name="upu">[http://www.upu.int/fileadmin/documentsFiles/activities/addressingUnit/andEn.pdf Andorra], [[Universal Postal Union]], September 2004</ref> ''[[Correos]]'' of Spain and ''[[La Poste (France)|La Poste]]'' of France operate side by side.
Both postal administrations issue their own postage stamps for use in Andorra featuring unique designs,<ref>[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/global-filipino/07/18/14/andorra-honors-pinoys-stamp Andorra honors Pinoys with a stamp], Daniel Infante Tuaño, [[ABS-CBN]], July 18, 2014</ref> as those of Spain and France are not valid.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=WttmSt7kPmMC&pg=PA412&lpg=PA412&dq=postal+services+in+andorra+stamps&source=bl&ots=YCYZs8vrA2&sig=RP8qMW_RjpZX002om9FLfNZQ6Uo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDwQ6AEwBWoVChMI25Lk7_7MxgIVJ89yCh1yogqo#v=onepage&q=postal%20services%20in%20andorra%20stamps&f=true ''Spain''], Damien Simonis, Lonely Planet, 2007, page 412</ref>
== French stamps == The 1931 issues were those of France overprinted "ANDORRE".
Its first set of stamps was produced in 1932 inscribed "Vallees d'Andorre", which depicted churches such as Our Lady's Chapel, [[Meritxell]] and St. Michael's Church, [[Engolasters]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Stamps of the World|publisher=[[Stanley Gibbons]]|year=2004|page=68}}</ref>
== Spanish stamps ==
In 1928 Spanish stamps were overprinted "CORREOS ANDORRA" for use in Andorra.
The first set of definitives was issued in 1929.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{PostalhistoryEurope}}
[[Category:Postal system of Andorra]] [[Category:Philately by country|Andorra]] [[Category:History of Andorra]] [[Category:Postal history by country|Andorra]]

{{refimprove|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Randhari | image = Randhari.jpg | caption = Official film poster | director = Mohamed Aboobakuru | producer = Hussain Rasheed | screenplay = | writer = | starring = [[Ahmed Nimal]]
[[Fathimath Azifa]]
[[Ali Azim]]
[[Ibrahim Jihad]] | music = | editing = | studio = Fariva Films | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2015|02|26}} | runtime = | country = Maldives | language = Dhivehi }} '''''Randhari''''' is a 2015 Maldivian film directed by Mohamed Aboobakuru. Produced by Hussain Rasheed under Fariva Films, the film stars [[Ahmed Nimal]], [[Fathimath Azifa]] and [[Ali Azim]] in pivotal roles.{{cite news|url=https://avas.mv/1951 |title=With over advertising, "Randhari" has been exposed |language=dv|publisher=''Avas'' |author=Nadheem, Ahmed |date=20 February 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160613083801/https://avas.mv/1951 |archivedate=13 June 2016 |accessdate=13 June 2016}} The film was released on 26 February 2015. == Cast == * [[Ahmed Nimal]] as Razzaq * [[Fathimath Azifa]] as Aisha * [[Ali Azim]] as Shahidh * [[Ibrahim Jihad]] as Waseem == Soundtrack == {{Track listing |extra_column=Singer(s) |total_length=12:39 |title1=Loaiybeh Vevidhaane Hey |extra1=Hassan Sobir |length1=3:35 |title2=Dharifulhu Dhoonya |extra2=Hassan Sobir |length2=4:35 |title3=Oagaatheri Hithakun |extra3=Hassan Sobir |length3=4:29 }} == Release and response == The film premiered on 26 February 2015 at Olympus. It performed below average at the box office and was digitally released on 25 May 2015.{{cite news|url=http://www.vaguthu.mv/evaguthu/maldives-film-industry/276537/ |title="Aniyaa" and "Ran Dhari" released |language=dv |publisher=''Vaguthu'' |author=Naail, Ismail |date=25 May 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160609171910/http://www.vaguthu.mv/evaguthu/maldives-film-industry/276537/ |archivedate=9 June 2016 |accessdate=9 June 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:2015 films]] [[Category:Maldivian films]] [[Category:Maldivian drama films]] {{Maldives-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox noble house |surname =Rastislalić |estates =[[Braničevo (region)|Braničevo]] |coat of arms = |country ={{flag|Serbian Empire}}
{{flagicon|Kingdom of Hungary}} [[Kingdom of Hungary in the Middle Ages|Kingdom of Hungary]] |titles =Lord (''domesticus'') |founded =before 1352 |final ruler =[[Radič Branković]] |dissolution =1379 (Eviction) |ethnicity ={{flagicon|Serbia|civil}} '''[[Serb]]''' |color =#bebeaf }} '''Rastislalić''' (Растислалић) was a Serbian noble family that held lands in the [[Braničevo (region)|Braničevo region]] of [[Serbia]] in the 14th century, initially under the Serbian crown and later under the Hungarian. They held Braničevo and Kučevo.[https://books.google.com/books?id=twYuAAAAYAAJ p. 169] ==History== During the rule of [[Stefan Uroš IV Dušan|Stefan Uroš IV Dušan 'the Mighty']] (r. 1331-1355), [[Branko Rastislalić|Branko]] (d. 1352) gained control of the Braničevo region, he was accidentally killed during a hunt by ''voivode'' [[Vuk Kosača]], his relatives later [[Krvna Osveta|avenged his death]] in 1359, when they murdered Vuk.Arheološko društvo Jugoslavije, 1968, ''Arheološki pregled'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=Ym8rAAAAIAAJ Volumes 10-11], page 96 The feud continued between the two families, [[Stephen Uroš V of Serbia|Stefan Uroš V 'the Weak']] was at war with Tsar Symeon, the Rastislalići turned to the other side of the Danube, where Hungarian-ruled territory in [[Mačva]] was held by Ban [[Nicholas I Garay]]. A Hungarian band was sent to take care of the enemies in Braničevo, and they became vassals of the Kingdom of Hungary.''The Serbs'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=sJJWEnXTHdIC&pg=PA80 p. 80] In 1359, perhaps at their invitation, [[Louis I of Hungary]] marched into Serbia and defeated Uroš V.''The realm of St. Stephen: a history of medieval Hungary, 895-1526'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=vEJNBqanT_8C&pg=PA164 p. 164] [[Radič Branković]] was the last feudal lord; he was evicted in 1379 by [[Knez (title)|Knez]] [[Lazar of Serbia|Lazar]] who issued a military action against him.[http://www.srpska-mreza.com/bookstore/kosovo/kosovo10.htm] The family also issued a regional [[currency]], the "Helmet dinars"''Coinage in South Eastern Europe, 820-1396'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=-FNmAAAAMAAJ&q=rastislalic p. 308] one of only three to be created prior to the end of the [[Serbian Empire]] in 1371.{{cite web| title = Numismatic Literature| url = http://www.numismatics.org/numlit/dates144.html| publisher = The American Numismatic Society | accessdate = 2007-04-07 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070403081922/http://www.numismatics.org/numlit/dates144.html |archivedate = 2007-04-03}} (Summary of "Mihajlovic, Vojislav. ''Novac srpskih velikasa iz vremena carstva''. Belgrade (2000)") ==Members== * [[Branko Rastislalić]], ''domesticus'' of Podunavlje (d. 1352), Serbian crown ** [[Radič Branković]], Lord of Braničevo -1379, under Hungarian crown * Brajko, nobleman * Raosav, nobleman ==References== {{reflist|2}} ===Further reading=== * [http://www.rastko.rs/istorija/loza_nemanjica/fajfric-svloza_5.html Zeljko Fajfrić: Sveta loza Stefana Nemanje] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110726125303/http://www.graduzice.org/userfiles/files/oblasnigospodariu14veku.pdf Oblasni gospodari u 14. veku] (Serbian) {{Serbian noble houses}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rastislalic noble family}} [[Category:Rastislalić noble family| ]] [[Category:Serbian Empire]] [[Category:14th century in Serbia]] [[Category:Serbian noble families]] {{Serbia-stub}}

{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Sandomierz |latin = Dioecesis Sandomiriensis |local = Diecezja Sandomierska |image = Sandomierz Katedra1.jpg |image_size = 250px |image_alt = |caption = [[Sandomierz Cathedral|Cathedral Basilica of the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin Mary in Sandomierz]] |country = [[Poland]] |province = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Lublin|Lublin]] |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Lublin|Lublin]] |rite = [[Latin liturgical rites|Latin Rite]] |cathedral = [[Sandomierz Cathedral|Bazylika Katedralna pw. Narodzenia
Najświętszej Maryi Panny]]
(''Cathedral Basilica of the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin Mary'') |cocathedral = Bazylika Mniejsza Konkatedra pod wezwaniem
Matki Bożej Królowej Polski in [[Stalowa Wola]]
(''Co-Cathedral Basilica of Mary Queen of Poland'') |area_km2 = 7,850 |population = 683,597 |population_as_of = 2014 |catholics = 638,712 |catholics_percent= 93.4 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |metro_archbishop = Stanisław Budzik |bishop = [[Krzysztof Nitkiewicz]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= |emeritus_bishops = Edward Marian Frankowski |website = [http://www.sandomierz.opoka.org.pl/ Website of the Diocese] }} The '''Roman Catholic Diocese of Sandomierz''' ({{lang-la|Sandomirien(sis)}}) is an [[diocese]] located in the city of [[Sandomierz]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Lublin|Lublin]] in [[Poland]]. ==History== The Diocese of Sandomierz was created on 30 June 1818 by [[Pope Pius VII]] in accordance with the Bull ''Ex imposita nobis''.{{cite web | title=History of the Diocese | url=http://sdmsandomierz.pl/en/history-of-the-diocese/ | publisher=Diocese of Sandomierz}} In 1981, its name was changed to the Diocese of Sandomierz-Radom but on 25 March 1992 the [[diocese of Radom]] was split off as part of a reorganization of the church in Poland by [[Pope John Paul II]] which added to Sandomierz 7 deaneries from Przemysl, two from Lublin and one from Tarnow. ==Leadership== * [[Bishop]]s of Sandomierz (Roman rite) ** Bishop Krzysztof Nitkiewicz (2009.06.13 – ...) ** Bishop [[Andrzej Dzięga]] (2002.10.07 – 2009.02.21) ** Bishop [[Wacław Świerzawski]] ( 1992.03.25 – 2002.10.07) * Bishops of Sandomierz – Radom (Roman rite) ** Bishop [[Edward Henryk Materski]] (1981.03.06 – 1992.03.25) * Bishops of Sandomierz (Roman rite) ** Bishop [[Piotr Gołębiewski]] (Apostolic Administrator 1968.02.20 – 1980.11.02) ** Bishop [[Jan Kanty Lorek]], [[Congregation of the Mission|C.M.]] (1946.03.12 – 1967.01.04) ** Bishop Jan Kanty Lorek, C.M. (Apostolic Administrator 1936.04.26 – 1946.03.12) ** Archbishop [[Włodzimierz Bronisław Jasiński]] (1930.08.21 – 1934.11.30) ** Bishop [[Marian Józef Ryx]] (1910.04.07 – 1930.06.03) ** Bishop [[Stefan Aleksander Zwierowicz]] (1902.09.02 – 1908.01.04) ** Bishop [[Antoni Ksawery Sotkiewicz]] (1883.03.15 – 1901.05.03) ** Bishop [[Józef Michał Juszyński]] (1859.04.16 – 1880.11.24) ** Bishop [[Józef Joachim Goldtmann]] (1844.01.25 – 1852.03.27) ** Bishop-elect (died before consecration) [[Klemens Bąkiewicz]] (1840.08.09 – 1842.01.02) ** Fr. Klemens Bąkiewicz (Apostolic Administrator 1831 – 1840.08.09) ** Bishop [[Adam Prosper Burzyński]] (1819.10.05 – 1830.09.09) ** Archbishop [[Szczepan Hołowczyc]] (1819.07.06 – 1819.12.17) ==See also== *[[Roman Catholicism in Poland]] *[[The Lesser Polish Way]] ==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/sand1.htm GCatholic.org] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dsarz.html Catholic Hierarchy] ==External links== * {{official|http://www.sandomierz.opoka.org.pl}} {{Roman Catholic dioceses in Poland}} {{coord|50.6766|N|21.7496|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sandomierz}} [[Category:Sandomierz|Diocese of Sandomierz]] [[Category:Roman Catholic Diocese of Sandomierz]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1818]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Poland]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses and prelatures established in the 19th century]] [[Category:1818 establishments in Poland]] {{Poland-stub}} {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Use British English|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox settlement | name = Scott's Hut | official_name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | settlement_type = [[Research stations in Antarctica|Antarctic base]] | image_skyline = Cape Evans Scott's Hut.jpg | imagesize = 300 | image_caption = Antarctica Delta Trip to Cape Evans Scott's Hut | image_flag = | flag_size = 110px | flag_border = no | flag_alt = | image_seal = | seal_alt = | image_shield = | shield_alt = | nickname = | motto = | image_map = | mapsize = 350px | map_alt = | map_caption = | pushpin_map = Antarctica | pushpin_map_alt = Location of Scott's Hut in Antarctica | pushpin_map_caption = Location of Scott's Hut in [[Antarctica]] | pushpin_mapsize = 300 | pushpin_relief = yes | pushpin_label_position = | coordinates = {{coord|77.636051|S|166.417646|E|format=dms|region:AQ|display=inline,title}} | coor_pinpoint = | coordinates_footnotes = | subdivision_type = Country | subdivision_name = {{flagcountry|New Zealand}} | subdivision_type1 = [[Antarctica|Location in Antarctica]] | subdivision_name1 = [[Cape Evans]]
[[Ross Island]]
[[Antarctica]] | subdivision_type2 = | subdivision_name2 = | subdivision_type3 = Administered by | subdivision_name3 = [[Terra Nova Expedition]] | established_title = Established | established_date = {{start date and age|1918|01|18|df=y}} | extinct_title = Evacuated | extinct_date = | named_for = Captain [[Robert Falcon Scott]] | founder = | elevation_m = | population_as_of = | population_footnotes = | population_total = {{bulleted list|Up to 25}} | population_density_km2 = auto | population_note = | population_demonym = | timezone1 = | utc_offset1 = | timezone1_DST = | utc_offset1_DST = | blank_name_sec1 = Type | blank_info_sec1 = All year-round | blank1_name_sec1 = Period | blank1_info_sec1 = Annual | blank2_name_sec1 = Status | blank2_info_sec1 = Restored and preserved | blank_name_sec2 = Facilities | blank_info_sec2 = | postal_code_type = | postal_code = | area_code_type = | area_code = | iso_code = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Scott's Hut''' is a building located on the north shore of [[Cape Evans]] on [[Ross Island]] in [[Antarctica]]. It was erected in 1911 by the [[Terra Nova Expedition|British Antarctic Expedition of 1910–1913]] (also known as the [[Terra Nova (ship)|Terra Nova]] Expedition) led by [[Robert Falcon Scott]]. In selecting a base of operations for the 1910–1913 Expedition, Scott rejected the notion of reoccupying the [[Discovery Hut|hut]] he had built by [[McMurdo Sound]] during the [[Discovery Expedition]] of 1901–1904. This first hut was located at [[Hut Point Peninsula|Hut Point]], 20 km south of [[Cape Evans]]. Two factors influenced this decision. One was that the hut was extremely cold for living quarters and the other was that Scott's ship, the ''[[RRS Discovery|Discovery]]'', had been trapped by sea ice at Hut Point, a problem he hoped to avoid by establishing his new base farther north. Some confusion arises because [[Discovery Hut]] can technically be referred to as ''Scott's'' hut, in that his expedition built it, and it was his base ashore during the 1901–1904 expedition, but the title ''Scott's Hut'' popularly belongs to the building erected in 1911 at Cape Evans. == Description == [[File:Cape Evans - Inside Scott's Hut.jpg|thumb|300px|Interior showing beds]] Scott's Hut was prefabricated in England before being brought south by ship. It is rectangular, {{convert|50|ft}} long and {{convert|25|ft}} wide. Insulation was provided by seaweed sewn into a quilt, placed between double-planked inner and outer walls. The roof was a sandwich of three layers of plank and two layers of rubber ply enclosing more quilted seaweed. Lighting was provided by acetylene gas, and heating came from the kitchen and a supplementary stove using coal as fuel. [[Apsley Cherry-Garrard]] wrote that the hut was divided into separate areas for sleeping and working by a bulkhead made of boxes of stores. A stable building (for nineteen Siberian ponies), approximately {{convert|50|by|16|ft}}, was subsequently attached to the north wall of the main building. A utility room, approximately {{convert|40|by|12|ft}}, was also added later, built around the original small porch at the South West end of the main building. Considerable effort was made to insulate the building, and to extract the maximum amount of heat from the flues from the stove and the heater, based on lessons learned from the [[Discovery Hut]]. Terra Nova expeditioners described the hut as being warm to the point of being uncomfortable.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} A cross is erected on a hill behind Scott's Hut at Cape Evans, but this is not connected to Captain Scott, having been erected in memory of the three members of Shackleton's [[Ross Sea Party]], who died nearby. The cross erected in memory of Captain Scott and his polar companions is to be found atop [[Observation Hill (McMurdo Station)|Observation Hill]].{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} == Use of Scott's Hut == During the winter of 1911, 25 men of the Terra Nova shore party lived in the hut. From here Scott and his men set out on the ultimately fatal trek to the [[South Pole]]. Following the failure of Scott's southern party to return several men remained behind for a further winter (1912) in order to search for the bodies the next spring. In 1913, the Terra Nova expedition over, it was left well supplied with stores in the way of food and oil, and a certain amount of coal. The hut was reused from 1915-1917 by several of Shackleton's [[Ross Sea party]] after the [[SY Aurora|''Aurora'']], which was to have been the permanent winter quarters, broke adrift in May 1915, and went north with the ice, unable to return. The hut became the permanent living quarters for the ten marooned men, and thanks to the stores they were able to sustain life in comparative comfort, supplementing these stores from Shackleton's Hut at [[Cape Royds]]. In January 1917, after Shackleton had rescued the survivors, he had the hut put in order and locked up.{{cite web |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/5199/5199-h/5199-h.htm#24 |title=South: The Story of Shackleton's Last Expedition 1914-1917 |author=Ernest Shackelton}} Although abandoned from 1917, the hut and its contents are remarkably well preserved today due to the consistently sub-freezing conditions. == Preservation and decay at Scott's Hut == [[File:HSM-16 Terra Nova Hut.JPG|thumbnail|300px|Scientific instruments located inside the hut, as they appeared in 2013.]] After 1917, the hut remained untouched until 1956, when [[Operation Deep Freeze|US expeditioners]] dug it out of the snow and ice. It was found to be in a remarkable state of preservation, and included many artifacts from both the earlier expeditions. While some artifacts were taken as souvenirs at the time (and since), this hut has remained largely as it was in 1917.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} New Zealand and the UK have undertaken responsibility at various times since the 1970s to restore (largely by removing snow and ice) both Scott's hut and Discovery Hut.{{cite web |url=http://www.nhm.ac.uk/nature-online/earth/antarctica/about/index.html |title=About the Antarctic Heritage Trust | Natural History Museum |publisher=Nhm.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-08-13}}{{cite web |url=http://www.heritage-antarctica.org/index.cfm/default/ |title=Antarctic Explorers & Heritage Preservation | Antarctic Heritage Trust |publisher=Heritage-antarctica.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-13}} While the preservation of food in the freezing temperatures and dry climate has been noted, bacterial decay still occurs. Visitors describe the [[seal meat]] preserved at the Discovery Hut as smelling 'quite rancid', and some{{who|date=December 2013}} have expressed concerns that the fabric of these huts are being affected by fungal decay.Blanchette, Robert (2004). Research at the Historic Expedition Huts of Antarctica. Retrieved from {{cite web |url=http://forestpathology.coafes.umn.edu/addantarctica.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070624121800/http://forestpathology.coafes.umn.edu/addantarctica.htm |archivedate=24 June 2007 |df=dmy-all }}. == Historic site == Both Scott's Hut and [[Cape_Royds#Shackleton.27s_Hut|Shackleton's Hut]] have been included on the [[World Monuments Watch]]. Shackleton's was included in 2004 and 2006, and Scott's in 2008.{{cite web |url=https://www.wmf.org/project/scotts-hut-and-explorers-heritage-antarctica |title=Scott's Hut and the Explorers' Heritage of Antarctica | World Monuments Fund |publisher=World Monuments Fund |date= |accessdate=2017-07-26}} The hut has been designated an [[Historic Sites and Monuments in Antarctica|Antarctic Historic Site or Monument]] (HSM 16), following a proposal by New Zealand and the United Kingdom to the [[Antarctic Treaty System|Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting]].{{cite web |url= http://www.ats.aq/documents/ATCM35/WW/atcm35_ww003_e.pdf |title=List of Historic Sites and Monuments approved by the ATCM (2012) |accessdate=2013-10-27 |work= |first= |last= |publisher=Antarctic Treaty Secretariat |year=2012}} == See also == * [[List of Antarctic expeditions]] * [[List of organizations based in Antarctica]] * [[Winter Quarters Bay]] * [[Research stations in Antarctica#List of research stations|List of Antarctic research stations]] * [[Antarctic field camps| List of Antarctic field camps]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == {{Commons category|Scott's Hut}} * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/1695897.stm Scott's hut needs repair] ''from the BBC'' * [http://www.savethehuts.com/ Discussion on issues surrounding the future of Scott's huts] * [http://tiger.gsfc.nasa.gov/tiger03_11_20.html Photographs of Scott's Hut at Cape Evans today] * [http://www.polarheritage.com/index.cfm/anthutlist Index of Huts, Ruins and Historic Sites in Antarctica] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101204040341/http://www.wmf.org/project/scott%E2%80%99s-hut-and-explorers%E2%80%99-heritage-antarctica The page featuring Scott's Hut in the World Monuments Fund's 2008 Watch List of the 100 Most Endangered Sites] {{portalbar|Earth sciences|Antarctica|New Zealand}} {{Historic Sites and Monuments in Antarctica|state=collapsed}} {{Polar exploration}} revision.text:
{{otheruses|Talking dog (disambiguation)}} [[File:Gadajacy Pies.JPG|250px|right|thumb|14th edition of "Gadający Pies". Aleksander Janicki on the stage, on the left masters of the ceremony, Prus and Bikont.]] The '''''Talking Dog''''' ({{lang-pl|Gadający Pies}}) was a cultural event held monthly at the Piękny Pies (''Beautiful Dog'') club in [[Kraków]] from the second half of 2010 until March 2015, described as "an anthropological talking magazine". It was led by [[Piotr Bikont]] and [[Maciej Piotr Prus]]. Editorial staff of the magazine included both masters of the ceremony (Prus and Bikont), and also [[Aleksander Janicki (actor)|Aleksander Janicki]] (<small>[[:pl:Aleksander Janicki (artysta)|pl]]</small>), [[Edward Pasewicz]], Andrzej Pilichowski Ragno, [[Jorgos Skolias]] and [[Marcin Świetlicki]]. Since the premiere, ''Gadający Pies'' had 31 editions.
== History == The first edition of ''Gadający Pies'' took place in the second half of 2010. In November 2011 a special episode titled ''Gadająca Suka'' (''The Talking Bitch'') was held.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.miastokobiet.pl/gadajacy-pies-gadajaca-suka/| title = Gadająca Suka| accessdate= 2013-01-23| author = | publisher= miastokobiet.pl| work= | date = | language = Polish}}</ref> The magazine suspended its activity from April until December 2012. It was reactivated in January 2013.
Each edition of ''Gadający Pies'' contained performances by musicians, poets, writers and scientists. Each performer had only five minutes to do the show. Prus, who was the master of the ceremony, kept five red lamps and has been consistently turning each lamp off after one minute of the performance.
Among people who regularly appeared on the stage within ''Gadający Pies'' were [[Marcin Baran]], [[Miłosz Biedrzycki]], [[Wojciech Bonowicz]], [[Paweł Głowacki]], [[Maciej Miezian]] and [[Jerzy Vetulani]].<ref name=wyb>{{cite web| url = http://krakow.gazeta.pl/krakow/1,44425,11025265,Kulturalne_Odloty__Pies_pieknie_e%20klektyczny.html| title = Kulturalne Odloty: Pies pięknie eklektyczny| accessdate= 2012-02-25| author = Małgorzata I. Niemczyńska| publisher = [[Gazeta Wyborcza]] Kraków| work = | date = 2012-01-25| language= Polish}}</ref><ref name=dp>{{cite web| url = http://www.gazetakrakowska.pl/artykul/336564,pies-gada-o-wszystkim-z-wyjatkiem-polityki,id,t.html| title= Pies gada o wszystkim z wyjątkiem polityki| accessdate= 2012-02-25| author = Marek Lubaś-Harny| publisher= [[Gazeta Krakowska]]| work= | date = 2010-11-24| language= Polish}}</ref> Guest stars have included [[Paulina Bisztyga]], [[Rafał Dutkiewicz]],<ref name=dp /> [[Janusz Iwański]], [[Krzysztof Knittel]], [[Ryszard Krynicki]], [[Robert Makłowicz]], [[Pablopavo]] and [[Stanisław Sojka]].
In November 2013, the first edition of an international version of ''The Talking Dog'' magazine was held. Created by David McGirr, led by McGirr and Kevin Patrick Cullen, it was an event separated from the original ''Gadający Pies''. As it was led in English, its purpose was to integrate different Kraków communities and people living in Kraków that didn't speak Polish.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.krakowpost.com/article/7312| title = Talking Dog International – A New Breed of Entertainment| accessdate= 2013-11-22| author = | publisher= krakowpost.com| work= | date = 2013-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = https://www.theguardian.com/books/2013/nov/14/krakow-unesco-city-of-literatre?CMP=twt_gu| title = Krakow's story: a Unesco City of Literature built out of books| accessdate= 2013-11-18| author = Antonia Lloyd-Jones| publisher = theguardian.com| work = | date = 2013-11-14}}</ref>
== Gallery == {{Gallery |title= |width=160 | height=170 | lines=4 |align=center |File:Gadajacy Pies2.JPG | alt1=Maciej Piotr Prus (L) and Piotr Bikont (R). |Maciej Piotr Prus (L) and Piotr Bikont (R). |File:Bikont Pies byVetulani.JPG | alt2=Bikont as the "Talking Dog". |Bikont as the "Talking Dog". |File:The Talking Dog byVetulani.JPG | alt3="The Talking Dog" led by David McGirr and Kevin Patrick Cullen. |"The Talking Dog" led by David McGirr and Kevin Patrick Cullen. }}
== References == {{reflist}}
