revision.text:
{{Infobox newspaper | name = The Budapest Beacon | logo = The Budapest Beacon.jpeg | image = | caption = | type = [[News website]] | publisher = [[Real Reporting Foundation]] | chiefeditor = Robert Field | assoceditor = | maneditor = | advertisingdirector = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = 5 | foundation = 13 October 2013 | ceased publication = 13 April 2018 | language(s) = English, Hungarian | headquarters = [[Lancaster, Pennsylvania]] | website = [http://www.budapestbeacon.com Budapest Beacon (EN) ] [http://hu.budapestbeacon.com Budapest Beacon (HU) ] }}
'''''The Budapest Beacon''''' was an online newspaper that reported on current events in [[Hungary]]. It was published by United States-based Real Reporting Foundation, a news organization.
== Online presence ==
In July 2014, Hungarian news portals reported that ''The Budapest Beacon'' planned to launch a Hungarian-language news website that September.<ref>{{cite web|title=Új online újságot alapítanak az egykori origósok|url=http://index.hu/kultur/media/2014/07/15/uj_online_ujsagot_kaptak_az_egykori_origosok/|website=Index.hu|publisher=Index.hu|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Új lap indul ősszel – volt origósokkal|url=http://hvg.hu/itthon/20140715_Uj_lap_indul_osszel__volt_Origosokkal|website=HVG|publisher=HVG.hu|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Új lapot indítanak az "Origo-árvák"|url=http://nol.hu/belfold/uj-lapot-inditanak-az-origo-arvak-1474303|website=nol.hu|publisher=Népszabadság|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Volt origósokkal indul új netes lap|url=http://nepszava.hu/cikk/1027199-kirugott-origosokkal-indul-uj-netes-lap|website=nepszava.hu|publisher=Népszava Online|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Új portált indítanak a távozó origósok|url=http://www.origo.hu/itthon/20140715-uj-portalt-indit-az-origo-tavozo-felelos-szerkesztoje.html|website=Origo.hu|publisher=Origo Zrt.|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Az LMP egykori mecénása egy rakás Origo-árvával csinál online lapot|url=http://cink.hu/az-lmp-egykori-mecenasa-egy-rakas-origo-arvaval-csinal-1605171465|website=Cink.hu|publisher=Gawker Media|accessdate=27 July 2014}}</ref>
The newspaper was often critical of the Fidesz government.
A number of Hungarian and international media outlets have reported on Hungarian events using content attributed to ''The Budapest Beacon'', including ''The Jerusalem Post'',<ref>{{cite web|last=Sokol |first=Sam |url=http://www.jpost.com/Jewish-World/Jewish-Features/Hungarian-Jews-set-to-physically-hinder-Neo-Nazi-rally-in-former-synagogue-340454 |title=Hungarian Jews set to ‘physically hinder’ Neo-Nazi rally in former synagogue | JPost | Israel News |publisher=JPost |date=2014-05-25 |accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Sokol |first=Sam |url=http://www.jpost.com/Jewish-World/Jewish-Features/Hungarian-PM-assures-Jews-of-respect-despite-beginning-work-on-controversial-memorial-349918 |title=Hungarian PM assures Jews of ‘respect’ despite beginning work on controversial memorial | JPost | Israel News |publisher=JPost |date= |accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref> the ''GlobalPost'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/europe/140123/russia-nuclear-deal-hungary-power-influence |title=Russia muscles into European nuclear industry |publisher=GlobalPost |date=2014-01-23 |accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref> ''Catholic World News'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.catholicculture.org/news/headlines/index.cfm?storyid=20456&repos=4&subrepos=2&searchid=1310681 |title=Holy See, Hungary ratify modified accord : News Headlines |publisher=Catholic Culture |date=2014-02-12 |accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref> Xplatloop.com,<ref>http://www.xpatloop.com/search/?q=budapest%20beacon</ref> and Politics.hu,<ref>{{cite web|last=Bayer |first=Lili |url=http://www.politics.hu/20131108/exclusive-former-hungarian-minister-becomes-head-govt-lobbyist-in-washington-despite-position-at-independent-us-non-profit/ |title=Tamás Fellegi Lobbying Hungary Initiatives Foundation |publisher=Politics.hu |date=2013-11-08 |accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref> ''The Budapest Times'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://budapesttimes.hu/2013/11/18/poi%C2%ADson-pens-scorch-paper/ |title=Poison pens scorch paper | The Budapest Times |publisher=Budapesttimes.hu |date= |accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref> Mandiner.hu,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mandiner.hu/cikk/20140124_europai_zold_part_siralmas_a_paksi_bovites |title=Európai Zöld Párt: Siralmas a paksi bővítés | Mandiner |publisher=Mandiner.hu |date= |accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mandiner.hu/cikk/20140324_modern_magyarorszag_mozgalom_valoban |title=Modern Magyarország Mozgalom: Valóban? | Mandiner |publisher=Mandiner.hu |date= |accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref> ''[[Der Standard]]'',<ref>{{cite web|author=derStandard.at |url=http://derstandard.at/1388650591644/Ungarn-Beste-Geschaefte-fuer-gute-Freunde |title=Ungarn: Beste Geschäfte für gute Freunde - Ungarn - derStandard.at › International |publisher=Derstandard.at |date= |accessdate=2014-06-01}}</ref> and [[Gawker]],<ref>{{cite web|author=gawker.com |url=http://gawker.com/editor-of-hungarian-news-site-fired-after-critical-gove-1587023242 |title=Editor of Hungarian News Site Fired After Critical Government Report › International {{refimprove|date=March 2014}} [[File:Nasser Chrustschow Arif Sallal 1964 Nil.jpg|thumb|From left to right: [[Gamal Abdel Nasser|Nasser]], [[Nikita Khrushchev|Khrushchev]], [[Abdul Salam Arif|Arif]] and [[Abdullah al-Sallal|as-Sallal]] in Egypt (May 1964)]] A '''Unified Political Command''' (Arabic قيادة سياسية موحدة, ''qiyāda siyāsiyya muwaḥḥada''), also translated as ''Joint Political Command'' or ''Unified Political Leadership'', was agreed in 1964 between the presidents of Egypt and Iraq ([[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] and [[Abdul Salam Arif]]) as well as between the presidents of Egypt and North Yemen (Nasser and [[Abdullah al-Sallal|Abdullah as-Sallal]]). Both projects were parallel but not linked with each other. The ''Unified Political Command'' was meant as a kind of [[Provisional government|transitional government]] which should prepare the gradual merger of Iraq with Egypt and North Yemen with Egypt in a new [[United Arab Republic (disambiguation)|United Arab Republic]].
==Egypt and Iraq== [[File:Nasser and Iraqi Prime Minister al-Bazzaz.jpg|thumb|[[Gamal Abdel Nasser|Nasser]] with the Iraqi Prime Minister [[Abd al-Rahman al-Bazzaz|al-Bazzaz]] (left): Still in February 1966 the Egyptian-Iraqi ''Unified Political Command'' declared its satisfaction about the merger progress in both republics]] Therefore, on 26 May 1964 Nasser and Arif agreed to form a joint Presidential Council and a Unified Political Command on 16 October 1964. This Unified Command was established on 20 December 1964 and did include the prime ministers of Egypt and Iraq as well as the ministers of economical and financial affairs and social planning of both sides and should act as a joint supreme instrument and highest executive authority to establish the economical, political and military unification of Egypt and Iraq within two years. The Iraqi Abd ar-Razzaq Muhyi ad-Din (Abdel Razzaq Mohieddin) became General Secretary of the Unified Command. In July 1964 an [[Arab Socialist Union (Iraq)|Iraqi Arab Socialist Union]] was founded as political instrument to collect the support of the population and was formally united with the [[Arab Socialist Union (Egypt)|Egyptian Arab Socialist Union]] in September 1964. Also in September 1964 Egypt and Iraq agreed to unite their diplomatical corps and representations all over the world. In 1965 Iraq adopted the [[Coat of arms of Egypt|Egyptian coat of arms eagle]] and the Egyptian national anthem, declared Iraq as a ''democratic and socialist republic'' and announced a programme of nationalization. However, despite a few real meetings and sessions of this ''Unified Political Command'' the project stopped when the Nasserist prime minister of Iraq, [[Arif Abd ar-Razzaq]], tried to overthrow president Arif in September 1965 and when Arif died in April 1966.
==Egypt and Yemen== [[File:A meeting between Yemen represented by President Abdullah AL Sallal and Egypt headed by Abdel Nasser 14 July 1964.jpg|thumb|In July 1964 Nasser and Sallal agreed about the gradual merger of Egypt and Yemen towards a full union]] Parallelly, but not linked with the Egyptian-Iraqi merger project also between Nasser and as-Sallal a ''Unified Political Command'' was established on 13 July 1964. A joint government council of the Egyptian and Yemeni ministers should coordinate and integrate the Foreign, Defense, Economical, Social, Cultural and Information policy towards full unity. A (short-living) Yemeni ''Arab Socialist Union'' (later renamed) was established already in 1964 and, in fact, Egyptian generals and officers took over the command of the republican forces in Yemen during the [[North Yemen Civil War]]. This civil war, however, prevented any progress and when Egypt withdraw its troops from Yemen after the [[Six-Day War]] as-Sallal was overthrown in November 1967 and also this project definitively ended.
==Others== Similar ''Unified Political Commands'' and ''Joint Supreme Committees'' were planned and formed *between the Syrian president [[Hafez al-Assad]] and king [[Hussein of Jordan]] in Juli 1975 in order to coordinate and push the military, political and economical integration of Syria and Jordan. The project failed when Syria re-approached Egypt within the [[Federation of Arab Republics]] in December 1976 *within the Egyptian-Libyan-Syrian [[Federation of Arab Republics]] between Egypt, Libya and Sudan in April 1970. Later Syria joined instead of Sudan, but Egypt and Libya agreed to let a ''Unified Political Command'' prepare a more substantial union within the federation. The Egyptian-Libyan merger failed 1973 but on 21 December 1976 and in February 1977 the Syrian president Assad and the Egyptian president [[Anwar Sadat]] agreed to form a new bilateral ''Unified Political Command'' and a ''Political Supreme Council''. In March 1977 Sudans president [[Gaafar Nimeiry]] joined that ''Unified Political Command'' and all three presidents announced to form a new ''Federation of Arab Republics'' which never was realized and finally collapsed in November 1977 with the begin of Egyptian-Israeli peace talks. *between Syria and Iraq in October 1978 when both sides agreed to improve their military and economical cooperation and even planned to form a Syrian-Iraqi Union. A ''Supreme Political Authority'' (Committee) and later also a ''Joint Political Command'' was formed with Iraqi president [[Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr]], Syrian president Assad and Iraqi vice president [[Saddam Hussein]]. The project failed when Saddam Hussein replaced al-Bakr in July 1979.
==Sources== *[[Robin Leonard Bidwell]]: ''Dictionary of Modern Arab History'', page 426f. London/New York 1998 *Hanna Batatu: ''Syria's Peasantry, the Descendants of Its Lesser Rural Notables, and Their Politics'', page 282. Princeton 2012 *[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2506&dat=19650606&id=MZxIAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uwoNAAAAIBAJ&pg=758,873107 The News and Courier, 6th of June 1965: ''Despite Alliance, Iraq, UAR Never May Be United''] *[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1350&dat=19641221&id=XghPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UgEEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7428,6212247 Toledo Blade, 21st of December 1964: ''Unified Political Command Formed for UAR, Iraq''] *[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1301&dat=19650127&id=KqpWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AOgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4375,7525222 The Sydney Morning Herald, 27th of January 1965: ''Mirage In The Middle East''] *[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1338&dat=19720802&id=ULozAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oPgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4422,390352 Spokane Daily Chronicle, 2nd of August 1972: ''Egypt, Libya Plan to Join as One State''] *[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1665&dat=19770225&id=HSAaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PiUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6461,5367119 The Times, 25th of February 1977: ''Sudan Expetected to Join Egypt, Syria in Command''] {{Arab nationalism}} [[Category:20th century in Egypt]] [[Category:Arab nationalism in Egypt]] [[Category:Arab nationalism in Iraq]] [[Category:Arab nationalism in Syria]] [[Category:Arab nationalism in Yemen]] [[Category:Arab Socialist Union]] [[Category:Egypt–Iraq relations]] [[Category:Former confederations]] [[Category:Pan-Arabism]] [[Category:Proposed countries]] [[Category:United Arab Republic]]

{{Infobox military installation | name = Wardija Battery | native_name = Batterija tal-Wardija | location = [[St. Paul's Bay]], [[Malta]] | image = [[File:Wardija Battery 32.jpg|300px]] | caption = Military helipad (left) and
gun emplacement (right) | type = [[Artillery battery]] | coordinates = {{coord|35|56|36.8|N|14|23|59.9|E|type:landmark|display=inline}} | ownership = [[Government of Malta]] | controlledby = Abandoned and dilapidated | open_to_public = Yes | site_area = | built = 1915 | used = 1915–1938 | builder = [[British Empire]] | materials = Reinforced concrete | height = | condition = Intact | battles = [[World War I]] | events = Historic landmark | garrison = Western Section Royal Garrison Artillery }} '''Wardija Battery''' ({{lang-mt|Batterija tal-Wardija}}) was an [[artillery battery]] in [[Wardija]], a [[Wardija Ridge|hilltop]] in the limits of [[St. Paul's Bay]], on the northern coast of [[Malta]]. It was built by the [[British Empire|British]] in 1915, and saw use during [[World War I]]. It became obsolete following the construction of [[Fort Campbell (Malta)|Fort Campbell]] in 1938. ==History== In October 1914, the British authorities made St. Paul's Bay an examination anchorage, and decided to build a battery to identify shipping on the way to the [[Grand Harbour]], and fire [[warning shot]]s to ships who were not obeying the regulations. In May 1915, two submarines were sighted off Malta outside the range of coastal artillery, hastening the need to build a battery in the north of the island.{{cite news|last1=Debono|first1=Charles|title=Major land, sea, air offensives during the first half of 1915|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20150426/life-features/major-land-sea-air-offensives-during-the-first-half-of-1915.565835 |work=[[Times of Malta]] |date=26 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150612140838/http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20150426/life-features/major-land-sea-air-offensives-during-the-first-half-of-1915.565835 |archivedate=12 June 2015}} [[File:Wardija Battery 11.jpg|thumb|left|One of the gun emplacements]] Between 30 November and 10 December 1915, the [[Royal Malta Artillery]] removed two [[QF 6 inch /40 naval gun|6-inch QF guns]] from the obsolete [[Wolseley Battery]] in the south of Malta, and mounted them in a position on the eastern end of the [[Wardija Ridge]]. The site was naturally protected so no permanent [[fortification]]s were built, and the battery only consisted of two gun emplacements.{{cite web|title=Wardija Battery|url=https://www.geocaching.com/seek/cache_details.aspx?wp=GC56FWH&title=wardija-battery&guid=f81e8811-0b78-4289-bc58-f38802e28cd3|website=Geocaching|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151114203926/https://www.geocaching.com/seek/cache_details.aspx?wp=GC56FWH&title=wardija-battery&guid=f81e8811-0b78-4289-bc58-f38802e28cd3|archivedate=14 November 2015}} The two guns were designated ''Wardija Battery'' on 31 December 1915, and fell under the command of the Western Section [[Royal Garrison Artillery]]. The battery remained in active service throughout the course of [[World War I]].{{cite news|last1=Debono|first1=Charles|title=The western, eastern, Italian fronts in the latter half of 1915|url=http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20150719/life-features/the-western-eastern-italian-fronts-in-the-latter-half-of-1915.577427|work=[[Times of Malta]]|date=19 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151114203300/http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20150719/life-features/the-western-eastern-italian-fronts-in-the-latter-half-of-1915.577427|archivedate=14 November 2015}} Wardija Battery became obsolete in 1938, when its role was taken over by [[Fort Campbell (Malta)|Fort Campbell]].{{cite journal|last1=Spiteri|first1=Stephen C.|title=A general overview of the fortifications in the locality of Mellieha|journal=Arx – Online Journal of Military Architecture and Fortification|date=2004–2007|issue=1–4|page=44|url=http://www.militaryarchitecture.com/Arx/arx1_4_2008.pdf|accessdate=14 November 2015}} In [[World War II]], a gun Laying radar set was established on the site of the battery. Wardija Battery's two gun emplacements are still intact today. ==Further reading== *[http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20120103/opinion/Intriguing-public-land-issues.400850 Details] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Batteries in Malta}} [[Category:St. Paul's Bay]] [[Category:British forts]] [[Category:Batteries in Malta]] [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1915]] [[Category:World War I sites in Malta]] [[Category:20th-century fortifications]] {{Malta-struct-stub}}
